item.title: How to Upgrade Gorgofex in Reckoning (Black Ops 6 Zombies)
item.description:
The Gorgofex arrives as the exclusive Wonder Weapon found in Reckoning, the last Black Ops 6 Zombies map before Black Ops 7 takes the stage. With the Reckoning map being the finale of Black Ops 6 Zombies, it's no surprise that the Wonder Weapon featured would have some powerful upgrades, along with a way to tie up loose ends. Upgrading the Gorgofex in Reckoning has some dire consequences involving the fate of its characters, and players will have to pick who lives and who dies between Janus' head of security, Blanchard, and the scientist gone mad, Panos. Below are both upgrade paths for Gorgofex in easy-to-follow steps:

If you're looking for our easy-to-follow guide on how to get Gorgofex, then click here!

How to Get the Gorgofex C Upgrade (Save Blanchard/Kill Panos)

The video above is a full walkthrough of acquiring the Gorgofex C!

Gorgofex C is the variant that players can get if they decide to help Blanchard instead of betraying him, and listed below are the coherent steps that players will want to follow to ensure that they save Richtofen's ally, and get themselves a neat new blue Gorgofex upgrade.

Step 1: Speak with Blanchard in the T1 Executive Suite

After acquiring the Gorgofex, head up to the top floor of the T1 tower into the T1 Executive Suite. When facing the north wall, players can find a closed metal door, and interacting with the closed metal door will see Blanchard appear behind it. Activating this mini-cutscene with Blanchard triggers the first step to helping him stop Panos and avenge those lost at Liberty Falls.

Step 2: Push the Red Button in the T1 Project Janus Reception

After speaking with Blanchard, head back to the spawn where in the T1 Project Janus Reception with the teleporter, there will be a red button that no longer has a case covering it. Interact with the button to trigger a Maintenance Klaus, who will begin to work on one of the terminals in the reception area. Players need to defend this Maintenance Klaus from zombies, and the Gorgofex is great for this due to its charged shot, as that will suspend zombies in the air with anti-gravity to delay them. Once the objective has been fulfilled, the elevator on the left of the room will be deactivated, leaving only the elevator on the right, which leads to the Mutant Research Labs.

Step 3: Free Panos by Gliding Down the Quantum Computing Core Elevator

With the elevator to the T1 Quantum Computing Core shut down, players will have to take the elevator from spawn up to T1 Mutant Research Lab, where the path on the right has a hole in the floor. Players can jump down this hole to parachute into T1 Quantum Computing Core, and from here, they can jump down the elevator shaft. Deploy your parachute in the elevator shaft and interact with the red buttons, which can be found on the walls inside the elevator on the path down. As soon as all buttons have been interacted with, players will re-activate the elevator, and they will be taken back to the Quantum Computing Core to interact with Panos, who is now an electric orb.

Step 4: Defeat Blue-Eyed Zombies to Free Panos and Get Gorgofex C

With access to the Quantum Computing Core now re-enabled, blue orbs will fly around the room and infect zombies, turning their eyes blue. Players just have to kill these zombies until the orbs stop transporting into other zombies, which could take a full round of killing in this room. Players will know that they have killed enough zombies as all of the blue orbs will manifest in the central console in the T1 Quantum Computing Core, leaving Panos as an apparition who repeats the same line of dialogue.

With Panos now spawned, interact with him to transfer his soul into the Gorgofex gun, thus killing him, helping Blanchard, and receiving the blue upgrade with the Gorgofex C. This model fires powerful lightning blasts, and it can now be Pack-a-Punched for further advantages.

How to Get the Gorgofex N Upgrade (Save Panos/Kill Blanchard)

The video above is a full walkthrough of acquiring the Gorgofex N!

Gorgofex N is considered the "evil" variant of Gorgofex, for players will be required to betray Blanchard and help the villainous Panos. Below is a step-by-step guide on how to get Gorgofex N, provided that players already have the base Gorgofex at the ready.

Step 1: Talk to Blanchard in the T1 Executive Suite

Head to the very top of the T1 tower to visit Blanchard, who can be interacted with by visiting the metallic door on the north wall in the T1 Executive Suite. Speaking to Blanchard is very important, as it's the only way to trigger the next step.

Step 2: Acquire the Strauss Counter and the Life Drain Serum

After speaking with Blanchard, head back down the tower to reach the T1 Quantum Computing Core. Once inside, look to the central control terminal at the southeast side, where you will find the Strauss Counter that can be picked up, replacing your tactical grenade slot. With the Strauss Counter, head through to the T2 Android Assembly room and use the Strauss Counter to locate the the red zone, noted by "High" on the terminal screen in your hand. This should be behind a zombie barrier, opposite Double Tap Root Beer, to the left. Once located, fire a charged shot of the Gorgofex at the box on the floor, just below the locker that's fallen over. This will spawn the Life Drain Serum that can be picked up.

Step 3: Acquire the Clean Hood, PC Fan, and Tubing

There are now 3 items that players need to collect, and each of them has specific spawns that can be found below:

  • Clean Hood - Found at the north wall of the T1 Bioweapons Lab, the same room where you picked up the Cyst.
  • PC Fan - Found inside the T2 Dark Entity Containment room where the Forsaken is located, to the left of the Arsenal on a collapsed server.
  • Tubing - Found in the F1 Quantum Computing Lab area, behind a blue generator with white boxes in the same outside area as Speed Cola

Step 4: Survive Blanchard's Lockdown and Get the Gorgofex N

With the items mentioned above, head to the T1 Executive Suite and interact with Blanchard's door. This will see players craft the Essence Extractor, and upon interacting with it, players will have to survive for an entire 90 seconds with enemies focusing on destroying the Essence Extractor, so make sure you're prepared for the lockdown. After surviving the lockdown, Blanchard's life will be transferred into the machine, so pick up the vile and rush it back to the T1 Bioweapons Lab, as it slowly eats at your health. Place the vile on the same station where you picked up the Cyst in order to craft the upgraded Gorgofex, which fires acid rounds, and it can now be Pack-a-Punched.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: RPGs That Start Slow But Become Masterpieces
item.description:
Summary

  • RPGs like Mass Effect, NieR: Automata & Final Fantasy Tactics start slow, building rich lore and character depth for rewarding climaxes.
  • Games like The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky FC & Xenoblade Chronicles 2 demand patience for dramatic narrative transformations.
  • Kingdom Come: Deliverance exemplifies slow starts in RPGs, turning mundane beginnings into rewarding journeys of mastery.

In the world of RPGs, many games grab players from the first second with explosive action and instant drama. But a special class of role-playing games takes a radically different approach, embracing the slow burn. These games don't just test players' patience; they reward them tenfold with incredibly rich world-building, deeply layered character arcs, and unforgettable narrative payoffs that hit harder because of the quiet hours invested upfront.

Investing these early, quiet hours transforms the story’s eventual climax into something genuinely special. That's the difference between a summer blockbuster and an epic novel; one gives a quick thrill, while the other builds a world so detailed and characters so real that players might never want to say goodbye to them. So, here are RPGs that transform their slow beginnings into legendary finales and prove that greatness comes from savoring the journey.

Mass Effect

The Slow Politics Of Saving The Galaxy

Mass Effect
16
8.3 /10
Released
November 20, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood, Language, Partial Nudity, Sexual Themes, Violence
Platform(s)
PS3, Xbox 360, PC
Powered by

Mass Effect kicks off with a bang on Eden Prime, a tight, action-heavy introduction to Commander Shepard and the synthetic geth. But after this initial sprint, the game hits the brakes hard. Players are summoned to the Citadel, the galaxy's political heart, and the sci-fi shooter abruptly transforms into a sprawling, dialogue-heavy investigation. The main goal is to prove that the Council's top agent, Saren, is a traitor, but with little proof, players are forced to navigate bureaucratic red tape and run errands across the massive station.

The game's masterpiece transformation happens on the planet Virmire. It's here that the narrative stakes explode. Shocking revelations about the Reapers and Saren's indoctrination shift the conflict from a hunt for a rogue agent to a desperate war against a cosmic horror. The beauty of Mass Effect ’s slow start is that it lays a foundation of lore, character, and consequences. By the time the galaxy is on the line, every decision feels personal and crucial.

NieR: Automata

Existential Drama Beyond The First Ending

NieR: Automata
10 /10
9.3 /10
Released
March 7, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Partial Nudity, Strong Language, Violence
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, Switch
Powered by

NieR: Automata ’s opening is a kinetic thrill ride, but that pace is misleading. After the fireworks, players are left to wander a melancholic, semi-open world and grind through repetitive side quests. The real test comes after Ending A, when the game asks for a full replay with Route B, covering much of the same ground from another perspective. However, the game’s true transformation comes much further toward Ending B.

What follows, Route C, is not a repeat but a direct continuation of the story, and it's here that NieR: Automata blossoms into a philosophical masterpiece. The plot's scope expands exponentially with devastating twists about the purpose of the war, the nature of the machines, and humanity's true fate. The story hurtles toward its ultimate conclusion, Ending E, a transcendent, fourth-wall-breaking experience that cements the game as one of the most unique and powerful stories ever told.

Final Fantasy Tactics

A Political Thriller Hidden In A Grind

Final Fantasy Tactics
Tactical
RPG
Systems
14
8.9 /10
Released
June 20, 1997
ESRB
t

Platform(s)
PS1
Powered by

Final Fantasy Tactics is as brutal in its pacing as it is in its turn-based battles. Early missions are a harsh gauntlet, with players often hitting a wall at infamous fights like the Dorter Slums. New players can feel stuck—grinding for hours, rewatching unskippable cutscenes, and learning harsh lessons about positioning and planning.

But around Chapter 2, the clouds part. The Job System opens wide, granting access to advanced classes and combos, and the narrative unfurls into one of gaming’s great political epics. Suddenly, what felt like a grind is revealed as a crucible, for those who master the systems are rewarded with near-limitless customization and a story loaded with betrayal, ambition, and tragic heroism.

The Legend Of Heroes: Trails In The Sky FC

A Legendary Payoff To An Unassuming Start

The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky
7.5 /10
Released
June 24, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Animated Blood, Drug Reference, Fantasy Violence, Language, Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 3, PlayStation Portable, PS Vita
Powered by

The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky FC is the definition of a slow-burn RPG, demanding huge patience for a payoff of incredible scale. The story begins with incredibly low stakes, following protagonists Estelle and Joshua Bright on their journey to become Senior Bracers, members of a civilian peacekeeping guild. The pacing is deliberately unhurried, focusing on long stretches of dialogue as the duo travels across the Kingdom of Liberl.

The game's transformation is a sudden, narrative explosion in the final chapter. After dozens of hours of seemingly disconnected local problems, the plot threads violently converge, revealing a massive conspiracy orchestrated by the secret society Ouroboros. This re-contextualizes the entire game. The climax delivers a series of shocking revelations, culminating in one of the most legendary cliffhanger endings in RPG history.

Xenoblade Chronicles 2

Tutorials, Titans, And The Long Road To Elysium

Xenoblade Chronicles 2
9 /10
8.0 /10
Released
December 1, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Language, Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco, Violence
Platform(s)
Switch
Powered by

Xenoblade Chronicles 2 is a massive, complex JRPG, and its opening hours are quite overwhelming. Combat seems slow and confusing, menus sprawl out endlessly, and even navigating the map can feel like its own challenge. For the first 20 hours or so, it’s not uncommon for players to wonder what all the fuss is about. Around Chapter 3, once a full party is assembled, the seemingly disconnected combat mechanics begin to interlock like gears in a well-oiled machine.

The story, too, shakes off its early stumbles and begins delivering the kind of heartfelt character moments and wild plot twists that fans expect from the series. In the end, Xenoblade Chronicles 2 is a marathon, not a sprint. The first hours test patience, but those who persevere discover one of the most rewarding battle systems and emotional narratives in the modern RPG canon.

Divinity: Original Sin 2

When Freedom Feels Like Confusion

Divinity: Original Sin 2
8.6 /10
Released
September 14, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Sexual Themes, Violence
Platform(s)
Switch, PS4, Xbox One, PC
Powered by

The game starts by stranding the player, a persecuted magic-user known as a Sourcerer, on the prison island of Fort Joy. The Fort Joy area is dense, difficult, and notoriously opaque, with little guidance and plenty of ways to get outmatched fast. It’s easy to feel lost, underpowered, and overwhelmed by the sheer number of systems at play.

The transformation comes when players finally escape Fort Joy. By then, they’ve learned the ins and outs of the turn-based combat, environmental interactions, and creative solutions that make the game sing. Overcoming Fort Joy’s chaos isn’t just a gameplay hurdle—it’s the moment players master the systems and the world truly opens up to them.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance

From Medieval Mundanity To Mastery

Kingdom Come: Deliverance
10
7.6 /10
Released
February 13, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Alcohol
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, Switch
Powered by

Kingdom Come: Deliverance features perhaps the most thematically brilliant slow start in RPG history. The protagonist, Henry, is a blacksmith's son who is incompetent at everything. The opening hours are an exercise in mundane medieval life: running errands, collecting debts, and losing tavern brawls. But this relentless realism is by design. As Henry learns, so does the player.

The turning point is the slow realization that Henry is no longer helpless, a feeling that often begins after he receives formal combat training from Captain Bernard. By the time Henry rises to knighthood, the sense of progression is unlike anything else in RPGs. The game is the ultimate patience-testing RPG, rewarding those who embrace its historical simulation with a journey that transforms powerlessness into hard-won mastery.

item.title: All Pokemon Scarlet & Violet Codes (August 2025)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Working Pokemon Scarlet & Violet Codes
  • How to Redeem Codes for Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

By using the games' Mystery Gift mechanic, Pokemon Scarlet & Violet players can get their hands on all manner of great in-game rewards. These typically range from rare or hard-to-find items to brand-new Pokemon; all of which can help players on their journey toward being the very best. However, it's important to note that Pokemon Scarlet & Violet codes don't last forever, so players should be sure to redeem them before it's too late.

The following guide contains all of the working codes for Pokemon Scarlet & Violet , as well as step-by-step instructions on how to redeem them. We'll update it whenever new Pokemon SV codes are released by the developers, so fans of the franchise may want to consider bookmarking this page and checking it from time to time to avoid missing out on future freebies.

Updated August 7, 2025, by Tom Bowen : To celebrate players clearing the first Treasures of Ruin Tera Raid Challenge, players will be able to claim a shiny Wo-Chien. Available through the Mystery Gift feature using the Get via Internet option, the free Legendary comes at level 75 and has access to Giga Drain, Dark Pulse, Snarl, and Pollen Puff. Players can also get a free Tera Shard gift, which includes 100 Grass, Bug, Poison, and Fairy Tera Shards. After claiming their rewards, fans of the game should bookmark this page and check back here often, as we're always on the lookout for new Pokemon SV codes and will update the table below with any that we find.

All Working Pokemon Scarlet & Violet Codes

Code

Reward

Expiry Date

N/A (Get via Internet)

Shiny Wo-Chien (Level 75)

September 30th, 2025

N/A (Get via Internet)

Grass Tera Shard (100), Bug Tera Shard (100), Poison Tera Shard (100), Fairy Tera Shard (100)

September 30th, 2025

Fire Stone (1), Thunder Stone (1), Water Stone (1), Leaf Stone (1), Ice Stone (1)

Sun Stone (1), Moon Stone (1), Shiny Stone (1), Dusk Stone (1), Dawn Stone (1)

January 1st, 2026

HP Up Zinc (2), Protein Zinc (2), Iron Zinc (2), Carbos Zinc (2), Calcium Zinc (2), Zinc (2)

January 1st, 2026

Sandwich Ingredients Gift

January 19th, 2026

STRACKSU1T

Free Tracksuit (Scarlet Exclusive)

N/A

Free Tracksuit (Violet Exclusive)

N/A

NE0R0T0MC0VER

Kitakami Rotom Phone Cover

N/A

SB00KC0VER

Pokemon Scarlet Rotom Phone Cover (Scarlet Exclusive)

N/A

VB00KC0VER

Pokemon Violet Rotom Phone Cover (Violet Exclusive)

N/A

N/A (Get via Internet)

Mythical Pecha Berry

N/A

How to Redeem Codes for Pokemon Scarlet & Violet

Redeeming codes for Pokemon Scarlet & Violet is remarkably simple, though there are a few things that players will need to keep in mind. For starters, they'll need to be connected to the internet in order to claim their rewards. They'll also need to pay attention to the redemption method. Certain rewards can be claimed without a code simply by choosing the "Get via Internet" option. Assuming there is a code though, they'll need to follow the steps below in order to redeem it:

  1. Press the X button to open up the menu and then navigate to the Poke Portal .
  2. Choose the Mystery Gift option followed by Get with Code/Password .
  3. Type in the code using the on-screen keyboard and then press the OK button .
  4. Confirm the gift by pressing the A button , then wait a few moments for it to download.

Players will not need a Nintendo Switch Online subscription to redeem codes for Pokemon Scarlet & Violet .

Pokemon Scarlet and Violet

The most recent Pokemon Scarlet & Violet codes are STRACKSU1T and VTRACKSU1T , which will reward players with a free tracksuit.

item.title: Games That Spent The Longest Time In Development, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • The Last Guardian took over 8 years to develop, skipping a generation to release on PS4.
  • Duke Nukem Forever holds the record for the longest development period at over 14 years.
  • Star Citizen has been in development for 13 years, raising over $800 million and still not released.

While many fantastic games, especially in the indie sphere, can be made in impressively short amounts of time, that's not the case with quite a lot of games. Like many good things in life, great video games might take a lot of work, sweat, love, tears, and most importantly, time to make.

Some games, however, take way longer to develop than most would expect —and some of these turn out to not be great at all. It's time to take a look at games made by titans of the industry that still took way longer than expected to make—many of them at a time when games were expected to take a lot less time to release.

6 The Last Guardian

Over 8 years in Development

The Last Guardian
7 /10
9.5 /10
Released
December 6, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood, Fantasy Violence
Powered by

After the massive critical and commercial success of Shadow Of The Colossus, one of the greatest games in the history of the PS2, one would expect Team ICO's follow-up on the PS3 to come out quickly, but that just wasn't on the cards. It took so long, in fact, that The Last Guardian skipped an entire generation only to finally release on the PS4.

The Last Guardian might be Team ICO's most divisive title, but it's also the most gorgeous and boldest of the three. Some players had trouble dealing with Trico, an AI creature that behaves unpredictably, just like a wild creature would, but there's much to enjoy here by both newcomers and the more mature fans of the developer.

5 Team Fortress 2

9 years in Development

Team Fortress 2
8.9 /10
Released
October 10, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence
Powered by

Though it fell off the map due to Valve's shifting focus, Team Fortress 2 is the biggest inspiration for massive hero shooter titles such as Overwatch , and was once one of the most popular games in the world. Team Fortress 2 began as a mod for the original Quake— even before the release of the first Half-Life— then took its time growing and ultimately scrapping most of what had been done before to eventually create the game that so many know and love.

Ironically, what ended up becoming arguably the most humorous shooter in gaming history began its life as a very serious tactical military shooter in the vein of what would become Counter-Strike. That's what nearly one decade of development can do to a game.

4 Final Fantasy 15

10 years in Development

Final Fantasy 15
9 /10
8.3 /10
Released
November 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Language, Mild Blood, Partial Nudity, Violence
Powered by

Final Fantasy 16 took over 7 years to develop and release, but that still wouldn't be the crown jewel of Square Enix's slow game-making process. Final Fantasy 15 came out in 2016, but it began life so long before then that it even had a different name. Final Fantasy 15 began life as Final Fantasy Versus 13 , a game that was meant to be part of Fabula Nova Crystallis, aka. the world of Final Fantasy 13. As Final Fantasy 13 (5 years in development, while we're at it) failed to get the same love from fans as many of the previous games in the series, FF15 became its own, complicated thing.

Final Fantasy 15 got a divisive response from critics and fans alike, as it's very clear that the game is an imperfect mix of various differing ideas, likely remnants of what scaffolding was there before combined with what it the game wound up being. FF 15 is messy, but it remains a beautifully unique and sometimes incredibly immersive and emotional experience where most gamers will find at least something to like.

3 Duke Nukem Forever

Over 14 years in Development

Duke Nukem Forever
4 /10
Released
June 14, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Powered by

Duke Nukem Forever infamously holds the top spot in the minds of many gaming fans and historians as the game that took the longest to be released. Over 14 years is a long time, especially when the end result isn't great.

Though the 14-year development cycle isn't exactly accurate, as the developers scrapped and remade the game from the ground up a few times, Duke Nukem Forever still holds the Guinness World Record for the game with the longest development period. That said, some other games that are yet to come out have already beaten that time.

2 Star Citizen

13 years in Development and Counting...

Star Citizen
Shooter
Simulation
Systems
Developer(s)
Cloud Imperium Games Corporation

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

Star Citizen began development after a very successful Kickstarter campaign that started in the early 2010s. The game that promised players both sprawling space exploration, ship-to-ship battles, and even a uniquely epic single-player campaign called Squadron 42 has already released a lot of playable content, but is yet to achieve most of the things it promised, all the while still making a lot of money off of its fans.

They say time is money, so, on top of the nearly 14 years in development, Star Citizen has also raked in over $800 million from crowdfunding and in-game purchases, which—if converted into time units—would very easily make it the longest development time for a game ever. There is, however, a game that is yet to come out that has the crown when it comes strictly to time units.

1 Beyond Good & Evil 2

Over 17 years in Development

6 Images
6 Images
Beyond Good and Evil 2
Action
Adventure
Fighting
Systems
Released
November 11, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Powered by
  • Over 17 years in development.

The original Beyond Good & Evil might just be Ubisoft's greatest sleeper hit. Though it failed to reach the sales heights of titles such as the Assassin's Creed series, the original immediately captured the hearts of all critics and the relatively small number of people who played it. Still, knowing they had the potential to pull off a bigger sequel after extremely positive word of mouth, Ubisoft released a small CG teaser in 2008 for what would be Beyond Good & Evil 2 .

That's pretty much all that players got for nearly a decade, before the game resurfaced with an extremely promising gameplay trailer that showed a new protagonist free-roaming in a massive city populated by futuristic flying cars. It looked amazing—and still does today—but that would, once again, be the last players would see from Beyond Good & Evil 2 for a long while. Eeven with serious shakeups at Ubisoft that caused the original director to drop out, the game is still officially in development. Here's hoping Beyond Good & Evil 2 ends up releasing one day, as this remains one of the most promising games in Ubisoft's catalog.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Players Want Big Change Made to Competitive
item.description:
Marvel Rivals players want changes to competitive play, asking the game to add placement matches and have fewer rank resets. Marvel Rivals was released in December 2024 and quickly built an active community. Players of the NetEase title often express their opinions about the game, offering ideas on how to improve the experience.

Players have shared suggestions several times to make ranked matches more interesting. Previously, gamers argued that Marvel Rivals character bans should extend to all ranks, rather than just Diamond players and above. On another occasion, the community suggested that competitive matches should end when a player disconnects, arguing that the numeric disadvantage can potentially lead to a loss. Marvel Rivals continues to work on making the game environment fairer, and players have revealed which adjustments they want to see next.

Marvel Rivals Players Want Placement Matches and Fewer Rank Resets

On the Marvel Rivals subreddit, user hell-schwarz argued in favor of adding placement matches. For them, competitive play is currently defined by the team with the highest-ranked Marvel Rivals players. Meanwhile, the squad with the least experienced players has a frustrating experience due to the gap in skill level. Placement matches in competitive games are used to determine a player's initial rank, making it easier for matchmaking to pair them with allies and opponents of similar skill levels. Other Redditors shared stories of facing players in high ranks while their allies were much less experienced, so they agreed with the OP's idea.

The comments section also discussed a second change that the Marvel Rivals community would like to see in Competitive: a reduction in the number of rank resets. Players expressed dissatisfaction with how often the ranks are reset, which they consider excessive, preventing them from finding their “true rank.” As a result, several comments said they feel fatigued and unmotivated to grind ranked matches, having given up playing. Other players said that, because they are tired of the frequent rank resets, they now only play enough matches to claim the Marvel Rivals ranked rewards.

NetEase has not yet indicated any plans to add placement matches or reduce the number of times Marvel Rivals ranks are reset. It is important to note that the devs are actively working to make the game environment fairer, including features such as reporting smurf accounts in Marvel Rivals and, more recently, new penalties for players who abandon matches, which can lead to a competitive ban. Thus, players hope that the development team will address this feedback in future updates, making the competitive experience less stressful.
